meanings.definition: Make a long, high-pitched cry or noise.
meanings.sent1: The excited child would squeal with joy when she saw the puppy.
meanings.sent2: The brakes on the old car started to squeal loudly.
meanings.sent3: The mouse let out a little squeal as it ran across the kitchen floor.
meanings.sent4: The kettle began to squeal like a teapot about to boil over.
meanings.sent5: The wind made the branches of the tree squeal in the storm.

meanings.definition: A long, high-pitched cry or noise.
meanings.sent1: The loud squeal of the brakes startled the pedestrians.
meanings.sent2: The piglet let out a high-pitched squeal when picked up.
meanings.sent3: The cartoon character let out a comical squeal when surprised.
meanings.sent4: The microphone feedback created a squeal that echoed in the hall.
meanings.sent5: The child's delighted squeal filled the playground with happiness.

meanings.definition: Inform on someone to the authorities.
meanings.sent1: The witness decided to squeal on the criminal to the police.
meanings.sent2: He threatened to squeal if his friends didn't share the candy.
meanings.sent3: The spy had to squeal to save himself from the enemy.
meanings.sent4: She didn't want to squeal, but she knew it was the right thing to do.
meanings.sent5: The informant was ready to squeal about the illegal activities.
